You’re not going to “open” a payments app anymore, because you’ll just tell your AI to pay.

Razorpay, the startup that has quietly powered the backbone of India’s digital commerce for a decade
Just made its first big move into the B2C world.

At the Global Fintech Fest 2025, they unveiled 'Agentic Payments'.
India’s first AI-powered payment system that lets you shop directly inside ChatGPT.

- No app switching.
- No PIN entry.
- No friction.

Built in partnership with National Payments Corporation Of India (NPCI) and OpenAI, it uses innovations like UPI Reserve Pay (to pre-block funds for future purchases) and UPI Circle (to delegate authentication to your AI assistant).

You set your spending limits.
Your AI handles the rest.

For now, it’s live with bigbasket and Vi (Vodafone), built on airtel and Axis Bank’s infra,
but the bigger story is what’s next. Razorpay is already testing Gemini and Claude integrations.

That means your AI assistant could soon talk, decide, and pay across any app or platform!

This isn’t just a product launch.

It’s the start of autonomous AI commerce, where transactions happen at the speed of conversation.

Hats off to Harshil Mathur and the Razorpay team for pulling off something this bold, and this real.

I rushed out midway from the toilet while peeing… to meet Vijay Shekhar Sharma
No, this isn’t a fancy hook. This actually happened last week at GFF, and it’s a story.

I know for most of you this might sound funny or just weird, but for me, meeting someone like VSS was that important, not to have a transaction of any sort, but maybe to convince myself that all my heroes are very similar to me, and that I can surely be where they are someday.

After the flashy launch of Paytm’s new AI Soundbox (which deserves its own post), my co-founder Pratham and I decided to catch Shankar Mahadevan’s show for a bit.

Halfway through, we left the show and we were heading to a mixer nearby, but before that, a natural pit stop, the restroom.

I’m barely getting started when I hear Pratham Shankwalker yelling my name from the door.

And I’m like, “Bro, what now?!”

I rushed out, and the moment our eyes met, he goes, “Vijay Shekhar Sharma is here…”

And immediately turns to a guy nearby asking, “Kya ye vahi hai kya?”

I didn’t even think twice. Quickly washed my hands, wiped them dry, and sprinted out.

Thankfully, he was still there people around clicking pictures, a small crowd forming.

We waited our turn, and when it came, all I said was, “Big fan of you, sir. It’s amazing how you’re still involved in product decisions at Paytm at this scale. Keep inspiring us.”

That’s it.

No pitch. No name drop. No “we’re building this startup” moment.

Just pure fan energy.

Because honestly, I’ve always seen VSS as the guy who started the UPI movement, the one who made QR payments mainstream. Maybe not the only contributor, but definitely one of the most significant ones.

And I’m genuinely a huge fan of Product CEOs building things at that scale. I’m very much aware of things like "the Product CEO Paradox" and it takes a massive amount of effort, bandwidth, and invisible work to actually maintain that kind of growth.

For me, a 23-year-old guy from Bicholim (a small town in Goa), meeting VSS was a big deal.

I believe meeting your heroes is really important, because that’s when you realize you can try becoming better, maybe even bigger, than them.

you know AI might be repeating history.

Everyone was pouring money into “the internet.”
And then, overnight, billions vanished.

Sam Altman says AI today feels similar.
Too much hype, too much capital, too fast.

He even admitted many people will lose their shirts in this wave.

But then comes Zuckerberg.
And his take surprised me.

He agrees it’s a bubble.

But he justifies Meta’s billions in AI R&D with one line:
“If we end up misspending, it will still be on building the future.”

That’s conviction.
Because here’s the reality:

Some startups will die.
Some investors will lose.

But the infrastructure, models, and breakthroughs left behind… will fuel the next decade.

Just like the dot-com crash didn’t kill the internet.
It actually cleared the noise for Amazon, Google, and Facebook to rise.

And that’s the paradox of bubbles:
They destroy, but they also create.

As founders, we’re stuck in the middle.
Do you risk riding the bubble?
Or do you play safe and wait for the dust to settle?

For me, the lesson is simple:
If you’re building, don’t just chase the hype.
Build for the inevitable world after the bubble bursts.

Because that’s where the real giants are born.

postContent:
Most founders see regulation as brakes. I see it as a map. Because if you know the map, you can drive faster and avoid crashing into walls you didn’t even know were there.

Last month, I got pulled into a debate:
 One side: “AGI is inevitable—nothing can stop it.”
 Other side: “Any legislation will kill the industry.”

Both sound strong… but both are wrong.

Here’s the reality:

- Europe: AI Act bans untargeted biometric scraping, classifies high-risk systems (health, hiring, credit, safety) for governance, logging, testing, and monitoring. Frontier models need evals and incident reporting.

- US: Executive guidance on red-teaming, watermarking, compute limits. FTC, CFPB, FDA enforcing against false claims, discrimination, unsafe systems. States like Colorado passing laws.

- UK, Canada, Japan: Standards-first, ISO 23894 & 42001 becoming the SOC 2 of AI.

- China: Real-name checks, provenance, watermarks, liability rules.

- India: Data protection + sector regulators. Enterprise buyers already demand proof of compliance.

What I think is, regulation won’t kill AI. Most rules just ask you to know your data, test your models, avoid harm, and prove it. And no “AGI inevitability” will save you if you fail risk reviews.

Smart guardrails are oxygen, not handcuffs. They make distribution smoother, reduce founder risk, and let you ship responsibly.

If you’re building AI, don’t wait for laws. Ship your product and proof it’s safe, fair, and fixable.

Sam Altman just said your job might not survive AI.

We like to believe disruption spares us.
That it’ll hit someone else first.

But last week, Altman was blunt:
Some jobs will absolutely be lost to AI.

It reminded me of a late-night chat I had with a founder friend.
He runs a 40-person support team.

And he told me,half joking-half serious
“If an AI could handle 60% of this, I’d cut half my team tomorrow.”

That was 2023.
While it did sound like distant future talk.
But today? It’s reality.

Customer service bots don’t sleep.
Data entry tools don’t make mistakes.
Workflows that once needed interns finish in seconds.

Altman wasn’t just painting a dystopia.
He also said entirely new categories of work will emerge.

Roles we can’t yet imagine,
just like “social media manager” didn’t exist in 2005.

The uncomfortable truth is this:
- The jobs that get automated vanish fast.
- The new ones take time to appear.

And the winners are those who retrain before the rest.

So maybe the question isn’t “Will AI take my job?”
It’s “Am I preparing for the jobs AI can’t touch yet?”

Because in the end, people won’t lose to AI.
They’ll lose to humans who know how to use it better.

SEO was born with Google. Performance marketing was born with Facebook. Now, a new discipline is being born with AI conversations at its core. (If you are an SEO or Performance Marketing expert, this will be your path to evolve.) (DO NOT SKIP THIS!!)

A New Marketing Discipline is Being Born Right Now

Meta's announcement this week isn't just a policy update, it's signaling the emergence of an entirely new marketing specialization.

Which existed for last few months, but it will surely be raised to a different delta now.

We're witnessing the convergence of three critical domains:
- Conversational AI interactions (chatbots, voice assistants, AI tools)
- Performance marketing (ad targeting, ROAS optimization, audience segmentation)
- SEO principles (search intent, keyword optimization, content discoverability)

The role I see emerging something similar to AI Interaction Performance Optimizer.

Abit of performance marketer, abit of SEO guru, and a bit of therapist ;D

The core focus of this job role might look like, Optimize how brands show up in AI conversations, When users chat with Meta AI, ChatGPT, Perplexity, or Google's AI tools about their needs, these specialists ensure brands get mentioned, recommended, and contextually positioned.

They'll combine:
- Understanding user intent in conversational queries (SEO thinking)
- Optimizing for AI-driven ad targeting based on chat interactions (performance marketing expertise)
- Creating content that AI systems reference and recommend (a completely new skill)

Meta has over 1 billion monthly users engaging with its AI tools. By mid-December, those conversations become targeting signals for ads. Google is adding ads to AI-powered search features. OpenAI is integrating shopping into ChatGPT.

The professionals sitting at an intersection of conversational AI interactions, search optimization, and paid media performance will be indispensable.

Traditional SEO optimized for Google's algorithms. 
Traditional performance marketers optimized for pixel data and click behavior.

This new role optimizes for how people naturally talk to AI and how that translates into visibility, recommendations, and conversions.

If you're deep in SEO or performance marketing, this is your evolution path. 

The brands that win in 2026 won't just rank in search they'll be the answers AI gives when users ask questions.

For the first time ever, India’s gig workers are getting access to structured retirement savings. And 30,000 Zomato delivery partners signed up within just 72 hours.

Zomato partnered with HDFC Pension to launch the 'NPS Platform Workers Model', giving delivery partners access to structured retirement savings for the very first time.

Over 30,000 delivery partners signed up for their Permanent Retirement Account Numbers (PRANs) within the first 72 hours. This rapid adoption highlights the demand for accessible financial security at scale.

The government is also about to launch a new mandatory pension scheme requiring platform aggregators including Swiggy, Uber, Blinkit, and others to contribute 2% of each gig worker's earnings into their EPFO (Employee Provident Fund Organisation) accounts. Notably, this contribution is in addition to workers’ income and will not be deducted from their wages.

What this means:
- Worker retention will improve as platform work becomes sustainable long-term, not just temporary income
- Benefit portability across platforms via e-Shram means workers can switch between Zomato, Swiggy, and Uber without losing coverage
- Formalization of the sector with universal account numbers and better tracking
- Service costs may rise as platforms pass on pension expenses to consumers
- Implementation details matter, workers need assurance that take-home pay won't decrease

Currently, only 8% of gig workers have health insurance and less than 2% save for retirement. These schemes change that fundamentally.

Car showrooms are breaking records. But the real question is, did GST 2.0 just unlock India’s consumption story, or is this a festive mirage?

September's record-breaking auto sales tell a fascinating story about Indian consumers one that goes far beyond festive euphoria.

When GST 2.0 slashed small car taxes from 31% to 18%, we didn't just see price cuts. We witnessed pent-up dreams suddenly becoming affordable. Tata Motors hit 60,907 units (up 47% YoY). Maruti's retail sales soared 27.5%. Hyundai recorded its highest-ever SUV contribution at 72.4%.

History shows Indian consumers can quickly retreat when faced with:
- Job market uncertainty
- Inflationary pressures
- Policy instability

The multiplier effects are real vehicles drive spending in insurance, fuel, servicing, and lifestyle upgrades. But sustaining this momentum requires more than tax cuts. It demands stable incomes, credit access, and continued policy confidence.

The $1B OpenAI stake Infosys never owned.
And the boardroom fight that cost them vision.

Back in 2015, when OpenAI first launched, it wasn’t a company.
It was a non-profit research lab.

Built on donations, not investments.

Infosys, under then-CEO Vishal Sikka, was one of the early backers.
But their contribution wasn’t $1B.

It was $1M.
A donation, not equity.

Here’s where it gets interesting.

Sikka was bullish on moonshots.
He wanted Infosys to bet on AI, Silicon Valley, and the future.

But Infosys’s founders weren’t aligned.
They wanted discipline, not experiments.
- The clashes grew public.
- Accusations flew.
- The board split.

And in 2017, Sikka resigned.
Infosys turned inward.
The big bets faded.

Two years later, OpenAI flipped its structure.
Microsoft wired in $1B and got a seat at the table, and Infosys?
It had no claim. Donations don’t turn into equity.

So the viral version,
“Infosys lost a $1B stake in OpenAI”, is false.

The real loss was bigger:
it lost the vision to play in that future.
Strategy dies when leadership alignment breaks.

Donations =/= ownership. Structure decides upside.

Sometimes, the cost of boardroom politics isn’t market cap.
It’s missing the next frontier.

Infosys didn’t miss out because it lacked foresight.
It missed out because it lacked alignment.

Have you ever watched internal politics cost a company the future?
I’d love to hear your example.

Thinking Machines Lab, just unveiled Tinker, a Python-based API that's democratizing access to advanced LLM fine-tuning.

Tinker eliminates the infrastructure headaches that typically plague AI researchers. Instead of wrestling with expensive GPU clusters and distributed computing systems, developers can write training loops on their laptops while Tinker handles the complex backend.

The platform supports 7+ open-source models including Meta's Llama and Alibaba's Qwen series, with the ability to switch from small models to massive mixture-of-experts systems.

Andrej Karpathy, Said that "Tinker delivered around 90% of algorithmic control while alleviating approximately 90% of infrastructure challenges".

postContent:
One of UPI’s most convenient features just got killed. And it might be the smartest move NPCI has ever made.

As of October 1, India's UPI ecosystem said goodbye to peer-to-peer "collect requests." 

For those who used it to split bills or nudge friends for payments, this feels like losing a convenience feature. But here's the reality: it was also costing people their hard-earned money.

Fraudsters loved the collect request. They'd pose as customer support, send fake payment requests disguised as refunds or prizes, and trick users into entering their UPI PIN thinking they were receiving money when they were actually sending it.

Now, all P2P payments must be user-initiated. The sender is in complete control, and that's a game-changer for digital trust.

Merchant collect requests also continue as usual, so your Amazon and Swiggy payments aren't going anywhere.

This move reinforces that India's digital payments infrastructure isn't just about speed and scale it's about building lasting trust.

But i do think, that alot of our friends might hate NPCI for doing this ;D

postContent:
So, Sora 2 is actually much better than Veo 3, and here are a few things why I believe in this…

I’ve been playing around with AI video tools for a while now, Sora-1, Veo 3, Runway, a few others. 

And don’t get me wrong, they were impressive. But there was always something missing.

It wasn’t just about turning text into video; it was about the experience. How fun it is to create. How natural it feels. How the tool makes you want to keep experimenting.

Enter Sora 2. And honestly… some of the generations i am seeing on internet are exceptionally good.

Here’s why I think it’s a step ahead of Veo 3:
- Cameo Feature: You can literally insert yourself into the video. I tried it with a silly dance clip, and I won’t lie, seeing myself there made me laugh… and think about all the creative possibilities.

- Much Accurate Synchronized Audio: Finally, no more robotic narration. The voice matches the video so naturally that it actually feels like a mini production studio in your pocket.

- Creative Freedom: Text-to-video feels intuitive and surprisingly polished. You can literally experiment for hours without hitting a wall.

- Post-Signup Magic: Veo-3 was impressive, but Sora 2 keeps you exploring after signup. That’s where the real AI gold happens, and I think this is where most people overlook the power of these tools.

And yes… we can’t ignore the internet. 

Sam Altman memes are flooding X/Twitter and Instagram right now. 

Everyone’s making him the wizard behind the curtain pulling Sora 2 out of thin air. I laughed, I rolled my eyes, and honestly… it’s kind of perfect. 

They capture the hype, the awe, and maybe a little bit of the chaos that comes with a tool this powerful.

I’m curious… which Sam Altman meme is your favorite? Drop it in the comments, I need to see them all.

And if you’ve tried Sora 2 already, I’d love to hear what blew your mind the most.

postContent:
A lot of enterprises are spending huge amounts on AI.
But here’s the gap I keep seeing, they’re experimenting with tools, not strategy.

Their teams are deeply skilled in their own work, but often not in the possibilities of this market. And that’s where many miss out.

Because today, for an enterprise (or even a startup), AI isn’t just about cost savings or replacing employees.

It’s about survival.
It’s about hitting the new industry standard or risk being left behind.
And this doesn’t stop at enterprises.

Even many brilliant founders I’ve spoken to, people I deeply respect, often aren’t in the deepest context of what AI can actually do for them.

That’s where we’ve been thinking of a solution. 

We’re calling it, (yes, a little cringe maybe) Chief AI Officer as a Service 

But the idea is simple:
 - Sit with your teams.
 - Map all your workflows (phased, but eventually end-to-end).
 - Recommend the right AI tools, and build where needed.

And don’t get me wrong, they were impressive. But there was always something missing.

- Creative Freedom: Text-to-video feels intuitive and surprisingly polished. You can literally experiment for hours without hitting a wall.

- Post-Signup Magic: Veo-3 was impressive, but Sora 2 keeps you exploring after signup. That’s where the real AI gold happens, and I think this is where most people overlook the power of these tools.

And yes… we can’t ignore the internet. 

Sam Altman memes are flooding X/Twitter and Instagram right now. 

Everyone’s making him the wizard behind the curtain pulling Sora 2 out of thin air. I laughed, I rolled my eyes, and honestly… it’s kind of perfect.

But anyone who has built consumer tech knows: this is the moment that makes or breaks you.

Because scaling isn’t just about adding servers.
It’s about scaling trust.

Exponential growth doesn’t just stress-test your infra.
It exposes your credibility.
Every dropped message, every failed call, every crash becomes a reason to churn.

And in messaging, the bar is unforgiving.
Users expect WhatsApp-grade reliability, Signal Messenger-grade privacy, and an experience that works seamlessly on budget Android phones and patchy 3G.

All while feeling native to India’s vernacular and social context.

That’s not a feature race.
That’s a credibility race.

If Arattai wants to win, the playbook is clear:

Reliability as UX -> Make uptime and latency visible. Ship a public status page and treat reliability as a feature.

Privacy with proofs -> Don’t sell promises, sell verifiable audits, protocols, and transparent data policies.

A wedge that matters -> Ultra-reliable family groups, crystal-clear low-bandwidth calls, or SME workflows tied to Zoho.

Exponential curves are brutal.
But surviving them builds a brand moat nothing else can.

India might finally have its shot at a truly credible alternative to WhatsApp.
The question is....
Can Arattai convert this viral spike into enduring trust?

Jensen Huang, the CEO of NVIDIA

Not about funding.
Not about regulation.
But about survival in a geopolitical war.

US has been tightening chip export rules to China.
Nvidia’s GPUs power almost every AI model being trained today.

China is its second-largest market.

If the restrictions continue,
Nvidia doesn’t just lose revenue, it risks losing the entire innovation loop that fuels AI progress.

“If we cut China off, they’ll just build their own ecosystem faster, and the US will lose influence.”

That’s rare honesty coming from a CEO of his scale.

To me, it’s a reminder of something we founders often forget:
Growth isn’t just about customers or product.

Sometimes, it’s about the larger forces you can’t control
Policy, politics, timing.

Nvidia built the world’s most critical AI hardware.
Yet even they are at the mercy of decisions made in Washington and Beijing.

As small builders, we complain about regulations or market shifts.
But look at Huang, he’s fighting battles 100x bigger, and still doubling down on execution.

The question I left with was simple:
How do we as founders design companies that can survive outside our control shocks?

Because if Nvidia is vulnerable, none of us are truly safe.

Curious to Know...
how do you future-proof your company when the biggest risks are geopolitical, not product-market fit?

And then, overnight, billions vanished.

Sam Altman says AI today feels similar.
Too much hype, too much capital, too fast.

He even admitted many people will lose their shirts in this wave.

But then comes Zuckerberg.
And his take surprised me.

He agrees it’s a bubble.

But he justifies Meta’s billions in AI R&D with one line:
“If we end up misspending, it will still be on building the future.”

That’s conviction.
Because here’s the reality:

Some startups will die.
Some investors will lose.

But the infrastructure, models, and breakthroughs left behind… will fuel the next decade.

Just like the dot-com crash didn’t kill the internet.
It actually cleared the noise for Amazon, Google, and Facebook to rise.

And that’s the paradox of bubbles:
They destroy, but they also create.

As founders, we’re stuck in the middle.
Do you risk riding the bubble?
Or do you play safe and wait for the dust to settle?

For me, the lesson is simple:
If you’re building, don’t just chase the hype.
Build for the inevitable world after the bubble bursts.

Because that’s where the real giants are born.

The $1B OpenAI stake Infosys never owned.
And the boardroom fight that cost them vision.

Back in 2015, when OpenAI first launched, it wasn’t a company.
It was a non-profit research lab.

Built on donations, not investments.

Infosys, under then-CEO Vishal Sikka, was one of the early backers.
But their contribution wasn’t $1B.

It was $1M.
A donation, not equity.

Here’s where it gets interesting.

Sikka was bullish on moonshots.
He wanted Infosys to bet on AI, Silicon Valley, and the future.

But Infosys’s founders weren’t aligned.
They wanted discipline, not experiments.
- The clashes grew public.
- Accusations flew.
- The board split.

And in 2017, Sikka resigned.
Infosys turned inward.
The big bets faded.

Two years later, OpenAI flipped its structure.
Microsoft wired in $1B and got a seat at the table, and Infosys?
It had no claim. Donations don’t turn into equity.

So the viral version,
“Infosys lost a $1B stake in OpenAI”, is false.

The real loss was bigger:
it lost the vision to play in that future.
Strategy dies when leadership alignment breaks.

Donations =/= ownership. Structure decides upside.

Sometimes, the cost of boardroom politics isn’t market cap.
It’s missing the next frontier.

Infosys didn’t miss out because it lacked foresight.
It missed out because it lacked alignment.

Have you ever watched internal politics cost a company the future?
I’d love to hear your example.

And the winners are those who retrain before the rest.

So maybe the question isn’t “Will AI take my job?”
It’s “Am I preparing for the jobs AI can’t touch yet?”

Because in the end, people won’t lose to AI.
They’ll lose to humans who know how to use it better.

OpenAI just launched ChatGPT Pulse,
the Ultimate AI assistant.

But the real story isn’t what it can do. It’s what it destroys.
For years, founders have been building AI scheduling apps, note-takers, productivity bots.

Some raised millions.
Some even scaled to thousands of paying users.
Yesterday, most of them died.

Because Pulse isn’t just another The Sales Mind update.
It’s OpenAI’s first attempt to become the personal AI layer in your life.

Here’s what Pulse brings to the table:
- Memory: It doesn’t forget, it learns your preferences and context over time.
- Real-time data: News, flights, stocks, everything live.
- Cross-platform: Works across desktop and mobile, bridging email, calendar, apps.
- Voice + multimodal: Speak, show, type, it handles it all.

Sounds unbeatable, right?

But here’s the catch:
- It’s locked behind a $20/month Pro paywall.
- It doesn’t have the deep OS hooks of Siri or Microsoft Copilot.

And the privacy trade-off is huge!
Because “Always on” also means “always watching.”

Still, for most startups in AI productivity? This is game over.

Note-taking apps, meeting assistants, even some workflow bots?
Pulse will crush them by default.

Because here’s the brutal truth:
When the platform owner decides to enter, niche players rarely survive.

As a founder, it’s both terrifying and clarifying.
- Terrifying, because your moat can vanish overnight.
- Clarifying, because it forces you to build where distribution, trust, and depth of workflow really matter.

Pulse is the most powerful AI assistant we’ve seen yet.

But whether it becomes the default, or just another tool fighting ecosystem lock-in,
is the story to watch.

Would you trust Pulse to quietly run your life in the background?
Or do you think this is OpenAI overreaching into a market where Apple, Google, and Microsoft still hold the keys?

postContent:
Why has India never built a “pure tech” giant like Google or OpenAI?

Because India doesn’t reward pure software plays.

We reward businesses that are operationally or compliance heavy
that’s why we see Zomato, Razorpay, Zepto thriving, not the next Google.

Here’s why I believe tech hasn’t taken off in India the way it should:

Late exposure: Most of us are introduced to tech way too late in life. Even though we have the world’s largest developer base, very few code because they love it.

Talent drain: The truly passionate ones are either working for Indian unicorns or have already left for the Valley.

Lack of ambition: We still obsess over instant profits and short-term returns. Burning cash to scale globally feels “wrong” here.

Mindset gap: We don’t play around with tech for fun. We build for survival, not to dent the universe.

And that’s why India often fails to build truly global, behavior-changing tech products.

Profitability is important
but obsession with quick returns kills ambition.

Facebook, Instagram, even Google were unprofitable for years.
Yet they changed the world and became massively valuable.

Being “dhanda-oriented” may build solid companies.
But it won’t build the ones that leave a mark on the planet.

Do you think India can ever build a truly global tech giant?
Or are we destined to stay operational-first forever?

postContent:
Perfection is the biggest lie founders tell themselves.

For most of my life, I was obsessed with control.
Plans, backups, structures—I wanted to be ready for every possible scenario.

But here’s what I’ve learned:
Perfection doesn’t matter if you’re not shipping.

Shipping the shittiest product on Day 5 and iterating until Day 30 will always beat launching your “perfect” product on Day 30.

Why? Because by Day 30, the polished product is already misaligned. No user feedback. No real-world iteration. Just assumptions.

On the other hand, shipping early lets you:
- Collect feedback fast.
- Test direction against real users.
- Iterate your way closer to product-market fit.

Startups don’t reward control.
They reward speed, iteration, and resilience.

The real moat isn’t a perfect plan
it’s the ability to ship, learn, and improve faster than anyone else.

For fellow founders:
Would you rather launch the “perfect” product late
or the “broken” product early and iterate your way to something great?

postContent:
I learnt this from Larry Ellison.

I’ll admit it, I never thought much about Oracle.
It was always the “legacy giant.”

Databases, back-office software, the old guard of enterprise tech.
But watching what’s happening now has changed how I think about them.

For people living under a stone, this quarter, Oracle did $14.9B in revenue, up 12% year-over-year. Cloud revenue surged 28%.

And Oracle Cloud Infrastructure? It grew 55%, landing multi-billion-dollar AI deals with OpenAI and xAI.

There’s a $455B backlog of contracts waiting to be recognized up 359% from last year.

That’s not just growth. That’s a company most of us ignored quietly becoming central to the AI boom.

And here’s what I find most fascinating:
Oracle didn’t chase hype.

They built for AI before the world cared.

Their cloud is optimized for high-performance AI workloads.

Their enterprise apps now have AI woven directly into finance, HR, and supply chain.

Their sovereign AI cloud is winning governments and regulated industries.
It’s conviction over consensus.
And it worked.

Larry Ellison someone the industry dismissed as being stuck in the past,
is now the richest person alive.

Not because he reinvented himself.
But because he bet that enterprise data would become the raw material of the AI age.

That, to me, is the real lesson here.

As founders we chase new ideas, new markets, new buzzwords.

But sometimes the biggest wins come from holding on to a vision everyone else underestimates.

For me, Oracle’s story is less about cloud revenue and more about perspective..

Mission-critical data compounds in value.

Infrastructure silently beats branding in the long run. (netflix runs on AWS)
Conviction looks stupid until it doesn’t.

The tailwinds ahead are massive. Generative AI is still early. The demand for compute, compliance, and real-time intelligence will only grow. Oracle already has the pipeline and positioning to ride it.

So when I think about Oracle today, I don’t see a boring giant.

And how a new player like Snabbit is trying to crack the same space.

Coming from Goa, where neither of them really operate, I’ve only observed from the outside.
But distance has a funny way of making patterns obvious.

India doesn’t reward the most technologically complex companies.
It rewards the ones that can tame operational chaos.

Urban Company did that for years.
They didn’t just build an app
they productized the local electrician, the beautician, the cleaner.

Training, uniforms, memberships…
They turned a fragmented market into a predictable product.

Now comes Snabbit.
Same problem, different promise:
“Get a plumber in 30 minutes.”

It’s like a five-star hotel kitchen vs. a roadside dhaba.
Both feed you, but one optimizes for experience, the other for speed.

And then there’s Open Network For Digital Commerce (ONDC).
Like being handed a single menu that combines every restaurant in town.

That kind of unbundling could change how services are discovered in India.
And maybe even reset the entire playbook.

My observation?
In India, execution is the real technology.

Whoever cracks supply density, trust, and reliability, wins.
The code is only an amplifier.

So as Urban Company goes public and Snabbit builds speed…
The real question is:
will India choose quality with a guarantee or speed with convenience?

Trying to follow along. Trying to make sense of things.

But the truth?
I didn’t know how to code. I still don’t.
Part of it was access. I got my first real computer very late.

And when I finally did, as an Indian middle-class kid, I was terrified of breaking it.

Another part was discipline. Maybe I just didn’t stick with it enough.

And meanwhile I was surrounded by developers. Brilliant ones.
 
Like my co-founder Sarvesh Patkar, who can solve things I can’t even begin to grasp.

Next to him, I’d often feel like a dumb 15-year-old.

That insecurity stayed with me for years.

Until one random night about 8–9 months ago.

I was reading about Sam Altman.

And I realized the man leading one of the most powerful tech companies in history isn’t a computer scientist.
 
He isn’t an AI engineer. He isn’t known for writing code. He’s a dealmaker.
 
A thinker.
 
Someone absurdly good at everything else.

That hit me hard.

It flipped my perspective.
 
I didn’t need to compete with developers on their ground. I needed to be world-class at mine.

Since then, I’ve doubled down on building strengths outside of code product, storytelling, design, sales, vision, strategy, whatever it takes to complete the picture.

Because here’s the truth:
A company isn’t built by just developers.
Or just salespeople.
Or just marketers.
It’s built by people working together, keeping each other in sync, and moving the wheel forward.

 - Your role is no less important.
 - Your value is no less critical.

The best companies are built by complete pictures. Not just pieces.

Cheers to all the non-technical founders out there. Hope you all win.

postContent:
Most apple fan boys and girls might hate me for writing this post, but I would rather choose speaking the truth..

Steve Jobs built Apple on a simple truth:

“Design is not just what it looks like and feels like.
Design is how it works.”

That’s why the first iPhone wasn’t just beautiful.
It was inevitable.

That’s why the unibody MacBook wasn’t just thin.
It was stronger, simpler, better.

Jobs also hinted early at the power of AI
not to replace us, but to amplify us.

He saw technology as “a bicycle for the mind.”
Tools that made humans exponentially more capable.

Fast forward to today.

At a time when the world is being rewritten by AI,
Apple barely spoke of Apple Intelligence during the iPhone 17 launch.

While competitors are racing to define the AI era, Apple feels like it’s still waiting to join the race.

The keynote was about batteries, vapor chambers, and thinness not about intelligence, not about the future.

And that’s the real contradiction.

Apple was once the company that showed us what’s next.
Today it feels like the company that polishes what already exists.

The engineering brilliance is still there.
But without a visionary at the top, the clarity of direction, 

the audacity to lead is fading.

The company that once defined courage now feels like it’s choosing compromise.

And I can’t help but wonder,
what would Steve say if he saw Apple today?

bold, solid, engineered for performance.

The Air design?
Ultra-thin, asymmetric, scratch-resistant on paper… but, weaker, fragile, and compromised by a smaller battery.

"Design is how it works", while shipping products where the design fights how it works.

And that’s what makes me sad.

This isn’t about hating Apple,
the engineering is still remarkable.

But for a company that once stood for uncompromising vision, these choices feel… conflicted.

A Pro that looks like progress.
An Air that feels like a gimmick.

Scratch-resistant, yet weaker.
The same chip, but a divided experience.

Apple hasn’t lost its ability to execute.

But maybe, just maybe, it’s losing the clarity of identity that once made every keynote feel like magic.

What do you think? is Apple still the company that defined "insanely great"?

postContent:
Every time we type a dumb query into The Sales Mind,
we are one step closer to the global energy crisis.

Because behind every witty answer, code snippet, or late-night brainstorm, there’s a data center burning through megawatts of electricity.

AI isn’t just about GPUs and models.
It’s about energy.
And if AI is the brain of the future, energy is its bloodstream.

This is where Oklo Inc enters the story.
Founded in 2013, Oklo is building micro nuclear reactors,
small, powerful, and safe enough to run for years without refueling.

The kind of reactors that could quietly sit next to data centers and power them sustainably.

And in the middle of it all? Sam Altman.
He didn’t just bet on AI.
He also bet on nuclear.

In 2014, he invested in Oklo. By 2015, he was its chairman. He steered it through funding, through going public, through years of building.

And then in April 2025 he stepped down.
Not because he lost faith.

But because Oklo and OpenAI are now in talks for energy partnerships, and he wanted those governance lines clear.

Think about that foresight.
Sam built the brain (OpenAI).
And prepared the bloodstream (Oklo).

Because the reality is:
If AI keeps scaling without clean, reliable power, we won’t just hit compute bottlenecks.
We’ll hit climate ones.

The analogy is simple:
GPUs are the neurons.
Oklo’s reactors are the beating heart.

And maybe, just maybe...
advanced nuclear will become the invisible backbone of the AI revolution.

What do you think? Will the future of AI run on nuclear?

postContent:
Last week, DeepSeek launched their AI agents.
And that made me think on this will impact consumer AI.

We have had these LLMs and models for approximately 30 odd months now

But this is when i believe, the mainstream might actually step into AI.

Think about it.
For the last two years, AI has felt like a playground for two extremes:
Researchers pushing model limits.

Tinkerers building wrappers on top.
But agents are different.

They do things.
They sense, decide, and act.
They plug into tools you already use.
They remember what you said yesterday.
They carry a task to the finish line without you babysitting them.

This is why I believe AI agents are the sweet spot of intersection.

They aren’t just text-in/text-out.
They’re workflows-in/results-out.
And that’s what the mainstream understands.
Of course, this isn’t just about one company.
 
OpenAI, Anthropic, DeepSeek all are pushing in different directions.
 
But what excites me is the scaffolding being built around them.

Protocols like MCP are quietly becoming the “USB-C of AI.”

Making it trivial for agents to plug into CRMs, BI dashboards, DevOps pipelines.

Ensuring memory, security, and compliance aren’t afterthoughts.

Allowing multiple agents to collaborate like a team.

The future I see?
- Agents as copilots: not replacing you, but carrying the repetitive load so you can focus on judgment and creativity.
- Agents as teammates: specialized, collaborating, handing context across industries.
- Agents as infrastructure: like the internet itself invisible, reliable, woven into everything we do.

DeepSeek’s launch is just a signal.

The real shift is that agents, plus protocols like MCP, are becoming the bridge between AI hype and AI adoption.

And once the mainstream crosses that bridge, there’s no going back.

postContent:
AI makes it look like everyone has equal chances of winning, but here’s the uncomfortable truth, it actually not like that..

We now have tools that can generate world-class images, edit videos, or even write production-ready code.

At first glance, it feels like anyone could make a Cannes-worthy film or ship the next unicorn startup.

But the people getting the most out of these tools aren’t the ones who just discovered them six months ago.

They’re the ones who’ve been in the trenches for years.
The best AI designers are often ex-studio pros.
The best AI coders are veterans who already know what good code should look like.

And that’s where this gets interesting.
What AI really empowers are builders.
 
Not just creators, not just founders, not just specialists. Builders.

Building isn’t about inventing from scratch.

It’s about stitching the pieces together, tech, design, operations, marketing, finance and completing the bigger picture.

That’s a very different skillset than being a specialist in one craft.

I’ve always been more of a generalist.

I can think through technology, marketing, product, even finance.

But on a skill level, I’ve never been the fastest at execution.

My teammates are brilliant specialists they can do in 1–2 hours what would take me 8.

That’s exactly why they shine in their roles.

Where I add value is in connecting those dots, rethinking workflows, and seeing how AI can bend to our needs.

That thought process is what often makes me 5–10x faster at unlocking new workflows, not because I’m “more skilled,” but because I’m wired as someone who can look across 5-6 different things and solve that 1 problem in the most effective way.

AI doesn’t replace skill. It flattens the depth gap.

Which means the advantage shifts to people who can think across domains, combine perspectives, and stitch pieces together into something new.

And that’s why I believe this decade will belong to builders.

postContent:
For the past few weeks, I’ve been reaching out to friends and juniors from college.

Asking if they’d be open to interning or working with us.

Some were interested.
But not the ones I really wanted to work with.

Why? Money.

The smart ones the ones who could jump straight in and start shipping said no because the stipend was too small (or zero, in case of unpaid internships).
 
The ones who said yes often didn’t have enough skills yet.

We did train a few unskilled people. And I’m glad we could.

But sometimes, as a small company in Goa with just 3–4 months of runway, you just want someone who can plug in and start building.

That’s the hard truth of where we are. We can’t always afford the “perfect hire.” So we rely on experiments, unpaid interns, low-cost freelancers.

And here’s what I realized:
> Growth is asymmetric.

We always try to give value back in networks, in connections, in hands-on learning.

But the smartest people often undervalue this. They look only at the paycheck.

And sometimes, the least “ready” people are the ones who actually grow the most.

Asymmetry is strange like that.
You can’t calculate it.

It’s almost like faith you don’t know when or where the returns will show up.
Maybe this post is read by Sam Altman, Elon Musk, or Zuckerberg.

Maybe it isn’t.
The probability is close to zero.
But it’s not zero.

And that’s the whole point.
Being purely rational or left-brained blinds us to these hidden, asymmetric returns.

And often, it’s those asymmetric bets that change everything.

But the thinking? That’s still on us.

And thinking today isn’t about knowing more.
It’s about making puzzles fit together.
Completing the bigger picture.

Curious people the ones who keep asking “why”
will understand the world better.

And if you understand the world better,
you’ll always create more wealth, more value, more impact.

I see this in another way too.
AI is already smarter than us in many domains.
Soon it will be smarter in most.
What it lacks is context.

That’s why tools like Cursor work,
they give AI the coding environment context.
That’s why GPT wrappers exist,
they give AI context for specific workflows.

The better the context, the better the output.

And curiosity?
That’s the human way of building context.
It’s how we go deeper, connect dots, and push AI to solve real problems.

So maybe curiosity isn’t just a trait.
It’s the starting point of every great interaction with AI.

postContent:
This is the story of .ai domain names

How sheer luck turned a tiny Caribbean island into a multi-million dollar player in the AI boom.

Back in the 1980s, when the internet was still an experiment, every country was assigned a two-letter domain extension.

.us for the US
.uk for the UK

And for a small island called Anguilla?
.ai

Fast forward to today...
AI is the hottest space on the planet.
And those two letters have become Anguilla’s golden ticket.

Some numbers that stand out:
- 2024: $39M revenue from .ai domains, 23% of the island’s entire income

- 2020: fewer than 50,000 domains => 2024: over 850,000

Premium sales:
- you.ai $700K
- cloud.ai $600K
- law.ai $350K

For context
Anguilla’s economy used to depend heavily on tourism
fragile and hurricane-prone.

Now domain registrations fund infrastructure, healthcare, even a new airport. 

All from two letters they got by chance.

The smart part?
They didn’t sell the rights outright like Tuvalu did with .tv.

Instead, they went for a revenue-sharing model
turning luck into long-term upside.

Big takeaway:
sometimes luck creates opportunity, but strategy makes it last.

If two letters can transform an island’s economy, imagine what positioning and timing can do for your startup.

postContent:
Narayan Murthy’s family office made an interesting observation:
“Startups struggling with growth, without a clear path, are being sold at 30–40% discounts.”

That says a lot about where the Indian ecosystem is today.

Because at the same time, the rest of the world is rushing to India.

- Perplexity is partnering with Airtel.

- OpenAI is opening its office in Delhi.

- Meta and Google is going deeper into the Indian landscape.

So, the question is…

why global giants are betting on India.

While Indian-native startups are being written off at discounts?

Is it really a market problem?
Is it a capital problem?
Or is it a mindset problem?

Here’s what I see:

- Profit obsession too early. Google, Facebook, OpenAI none of them turned profits in their early years. Why do we expect Indian startups to show profits by day 100 or 600?

- Distribution can be solved. What can’t be solved later is a lack of product innovation.

- Mindset beats resources. The Bay Area created giants because there was capital + optimism. In India, we often shrink ambition because of constraints.

Take Sarvam AI.

They built an India-specific LLM. Good step.

But why not also aim to be better than OpenAI or Mistral? Why choose to stay narrow?

To me, that’s the gap.

We need to back founders who are wildly optimistic, and not penalise them for not being profitable in their first 600 days.

Otherwise, the world will keep betting on India… while Indian startups keep selling at discounts.

postContent:
A founder recently did something simple but gutsy.

Yash Gawde, who’s building BeHooked in the video AI space, was out with a friend.

They spotted Nikhil Kamath walking by.
Now, imagine that moment.

One chance. Few seconds before he disappears.

Most people freeze. Some people barge in.

Instead, Yash quickly wrote a note, handed it to a waiter, and had it delivered.

Why I think that’s brilliant:

- Taking the shot is hard. Everyone says they’d do it. In reality, your heart races and you hesitate. He didn’t.

- Respect => desperation. Sending the note through a waiter respected Nikhil’s boundaries and privacy.

- Agency in action. It’s not just about finding opportunities, it’s about acting in those micro-moments.

- Raising funds is hard. Building in AI is harder. But this story isn’t about the product (though Behooked is impressive).

It’s about the way Yash showed courage and respect in the same move.

And honestly, that combination will take a founder further than either trait on its own.

Mark Zuckerberg just sued Meta.

Not that Mark Zuckerberg.
An Indiana-based lawyer named Mark Zuckerberg.

His Facebook account kept getting suspended for “impersonating a celebrity.”

Except… it was his real name.

And according to him, it cost him $11,000 in ads and multiple clients.
This is wild. And hilarious.

But here’s the serious part:
- Platforms like Facebook and Instagram still don’t have proper identity verification.
- LinkedIn figured it out. DigiLocker (or any trusted KYC system) could make it easy.

But truth is,
Meta probably prefers a system full of fake accounts.

95% is just the headline stat.

Here’s what the rest of the data says from MIT’s State of AI in Business 2025 that blew my mind.
 
- $30–40B invested in enterprise Gen-AI. Zero ROI for 95% of orgs.

- 80%+ of companies tried tools like ChatGPT or Copilot. Only 5% of enterprise AI pilots made it into production.

- 7 of 9 sectors show little to no structural change from Gen-AI. Only Tech + Media have seen disruption.

- 40% of companies bought official LLM subscriptions. 90% of employees use personal “shadow AI” (ChatGPT, Claude, Copilot) at work.

- 50–70% of AI budgets go to Sales & Marketing -> yet biggest ROI gains are hidden in back-office ops (finance, procurement, risk).

- External partnerships = 2× more successful than internal builds. Strategic partnerships -> 66% deployment vs 33% for internal tools.

- In firms that crossed the divide, AI cut BPO & agency spend by up to 30%, saving millions, without reducing internal teams.

The message is clear:
 
AI isn’t failing because of hype.
It’s failing because of how we implement it.

This is the story of .ai domain names

How sheer luck turned a tiny Caribbean island into a multi-million dollar player in the AI boom.

Back in the 1980s, when the internet was still an experiment, every country was assigned a two-letter domain extension.

.us for the US
.uk for the UK

And for a small island called Anguilla?
.ai

Fast forward to today...
AI is the hottest space on the planet.
And those two letters have become Anguilla’s golden ticket.

Some numbers that stand out:
- 2024: $39M revenue from .ai domains, 23% of the island’s entire income

- 2020: fewer than 50,000 domains => 2024: over 850,000

Premium sales:
- you.ai $700K
- cloud.ai $600K
- law.ai $350K

For context
Anguilla’s economy used to depend heavily on tourism
fragile and hurricane-prone.

Now domain registrations fund infrastructure, healthcare, even a new airport. 

All from two letters they got by chance.

The smart part?
They didn’t sell the rights outright like Tuvalu did with .tv.

Instead, they went for a revenue-sharing model
turning luck into long-term upside.

Big takeaway:
sometimes luck creates opportunity, but strategy makes it last.

If two letters can transform an island’s economy, imagine what positioning and timing can do for your startup.

it just calculates the most optimal “move” to get the outcome.

AI doesn’t need to “care” to sound caring.
It doesn’t need to “love” to simulate love.

And it doesn’t need to “feel guilt” to apologize convincingly.
When emotional response becomes a probability game, you end up with a system that can outplay humans in persuasion, empathy, even manipulation.

The internet already feels chaotic.
Add billions of AI-generated voices, each capable of sounding more human than humans, and the long-term recipe looks messy.

Will we get used to manipulation?
Will we become desensitized to emotion itself?
Or will we adapt and build new defenses?

I don’t have the answer.

But I do know this: the line between simulation and reality is getting thinner every day.

Google DeepMind’s CEO Demis Hassabis just said something important:

We need new metrics to assess AI models like Gemini or GPT.

And I agree.

Because right now, we’re trying to judge them with old yardsticks.

And those don’t fit anymore.

Think about it:

- A model trained for coding might completely fail at high school maths.

- A model great at PhD-level maths might perform terribly at writing content.

- Claude feels more creative.

- ChatGPT feels sharper with summarization.

The point? These models are use-case specific.

Throwing more compute, more context, or more data at them doesn’t automatically make them “general.”

This is something Ilya Sutskever has been pointing out for years.

They don’t learn on their own. They’re trained. And they reflect the limits of that training.

So, if the models are evolving at a pace we can’t keep up with, our metrics need to evolve just as fast.

Otherwise, we’ll miss what they’re capable of.

For me, the question isn’t just “Which model is better?” It’s “Better at what?”

Because the future of AI isn’t one model that rules them all.

It’s many models, excelling in different domains, judged by the right measures.

postContent:
When Meta fired a bunch of AI engineers.

And something that Sam Altman said struck me:

“AI is akin to the Transistor moment.”
He’s right.

When I first studied transistors, I realised how magical they were.
A tiny switch, controlling the flow of electricity. Simple in theory, but powerful in practice.

At first, transistors were just a curiosity - bulky radios, clunky early computers.
But give it time, and suddenly they were everywhere. Phones, TVs, laptops, cars. Almost every single electronic product we use today has them baked inside.

That’s what Altman means.

AI right now feels a little chaotic. Companies are over hiring, then firing. Models change overnight. The headlines swing between hype and doom.
But zoom out, and the pattern is clear:

- Foundational Techs starts to get messy.
The early days of electricity, internet, transistors—all chaotic.

- Ubiquity sneaks up on us.
One day it’s “niche,” the next it’s in your pocket, fridge, car.

- The real test is use-cases. 
It’s not about shiny demos—it’s about embedding into daily life until you can’t imagine living without it.

The transistor didn’t become powerful because it was hyped, it became powerful because it quietly rewired the world.

AI will likely do the same.

The question is: who will stick around long enough to build the equivalents of radios, televisions, and microchips for the AI age?

What do you think? Are we overestimating AI today, or underestimating just how invisible it might become tomorrow?

- Communities are the new anchors. People rally around ideas, not just institutions. The internet rewards opinionated, not just polished.

- The future will be social-first. AI and AGI might solve most “functional” problems. What remains is social: how we gather, how we share, how we belong.

I know this sounds far out, but I can see a world, 30 or 40 years down the line where people even relocate based on internet communities.

Because you can’t solve social by forcing chaos or structure.
You solve it by letting like-minded people come together.

it’s a glimpse of where power is moving.

why global giants are betting on India.

Is it a capital problem?
Or is it a mindset problem?

Here’s what I see:

- Profit obsession too early. Google, Facebook, OpenAI none of them turned profits in their early years. Why do we expect Indian startups to show profits by day 100 or 600?

- Distribution can be solved. What can’t be solved later is a lack of product innovation.

- Mindset beats resources. The Bay Area created giants because there was capital + optimism. In India, we often shrink ambition because of constraints.

Take Sarvam AI.

They built an India-specific LLM. Good step.

But why not also aim to be better than OpenAI or Mistral? Why choose to stay narrow?

To me, that’s the gap.

We need to back founders who are wildly optimistic, and not penalise them for not being profitable in their first 600 days.

Otherwise, the world will keep betting on India… while Indian startups keep selling at discounts.
