“I think the shortage today is not of technology or capital, it’s of great entrepreneurs who know how to make these choices.”

When you think about it, he’s spot on.

We live in a time where tools, capital, and opportunities are more accessible than ever. You can spin up a product in days, raise funds from anywhere in the world, and tap into an endless knowledge base online.

But the bottleneck? It's the ability to prioritise and go all in.

It’s the judgment to choose what to pursue, what to ignore, and when to double down.

It’s the ability to make hard calls with limited information and still stand by them.

As a founder building Frover, I’ve realised this first-hand.

Majority of your business problems can be solved, but all of them will come at a cost, cost of opportunities to do something different, may be abit better or may be abit bigger.

Its always on what you choose, to solve them or not..

But making those high-leverage, sometimes uncomfortable, choices is what shapes whether you’re just building… or winning.

Khosla’s reminder is simple but powerful: Entrepreneurship is less about what you have and more about what you decide to do with it.

What do you think is the real startup superpower today?
author: Siddharth Manjrekar

postContent:
Y Combinator founders are getting younger.

And their expectations? Even higher.

Garry Tan recently said this and honestly, you can see it in the cohorts.
Most are AI-heavy. Most are B2B.

And a surprising number are still in college.

Here’s the crazy part:

YC has now reached a point where just being selected can change your life.
Of course, the founders who make it in are exceptional, brilliant with distribution, product, and problem-solving.

But YC itself has become such a strong force that simply being in that ecosystem can accelerate you in ways nothing else can.

It’s no longer just an accelerator.
It’s a launchpad.

I’ll admit.....
I’m a little jealous of those who get in.
But more than that, I’m inspired.

Because every YC founder I know pushes me to think bigger, aim higher, and refine what I’m building.

And honestly, I’d love to pick notes from my YC connections here.
What’s the one thing you did to maximize your shot at getting in?
author: Siddharth Manjrekar

postContent:
A fresh contender is making ripples. 

Locals are calling it the ‘little NVIDIA.’"

The company? Cambricon.

It's a Chinese competitor to NVIDIA

This week its stock price doubled!
hitting an staggering $81B valuation.

What’s wild is:
- It’s already powering companies like ByteDance.

- Developers say it’s more software-friendly than NVIDIA.

And get this, in 2019, Cambricon lost 98% of its value when Huawei dropped them… 

only to bounce back as one of Huawei’s biggest competitors.

That’s not the usual script for semiconductors.
But they pulled it off.

For me, Cambricon’s rise shows something bigger:

- The AI chip war won’t be one giant vs the world.

- It’ll be fragmented by nation, geography, and geopolitics.

And that matters. Because hardware is the real bottleneck.

Software can evolve.
Models can improve.
But without chips, nothing runs.

I honestly believe hardware will decide 50–60% of how AI moves forward shaping not just markets, but also peace, conflict, and growth.

What do you think ? are we heading toward a future with world split into dozens of “little NVIDIAs” across countries?
author: Siddharth Manjrekar

postContent:
Jio just announced the Dhirubhai Ambani Giga Energy Complex and it will be 4x bigger than Tesla’s Gigafactory.

And built with enough steel to match 100 Eiffel Towers.

Here’s how I see it:

- Reliance isn’t playing the AI game the way OpenAI or Anthropic are. 

For them, AI is just one weapon in an arsenal that already spans energy, telecom, retail, and more.

And that’s what makes them dangerous.

Because when a company of this scale plugs AI into an ecosystem play, the delta it creates across all services is massive.

Unlike pure software players, Reliance has a unique edge:

- Capacity. They have the resources to go toe-to-toe with global giants.

- Breadth. They operate across sectors few others don't even touch.

- Reach. If anyone can crack AI adoption into Bharat, that is it's Tier 2, Tier 3 India, it’s them.

If they succeed, a new wave of India-specific consumer AI companies emerges.

Commerce itself changes, because AI finally penetrates where it hasn’t yet.

I don’t know how this will play out. But it’s one of the boldest signals yet that AI in India won’t just be about labs and startups.
 
It’ll be about ecosystems.

And Reliance knows how to build those better than anyone else.
author: Siddharth Manjrekar

postContent:
NVIDIA CEO Jensen Huang just said something bold:

By the end of this decade, $3–4 trillion will be invested into AI infrastructure.
That’s not hype. That’s real money!

And it tells us two things:

- The wave is inevitable. When trillions are committed, the market doesn’t ask if it will change, only how fast.

- Everyone has a stake. If this much capital is flowing, even the “small shopkeepers” of AI, startups, researchers, builders can grab a piece of the cake.

For me, AI isn’t just another hyped-up technology.

It’s the interface that will sit across industries, products, and even daily life.

So, no matter which field you’ve been in, you must start experimenting. 

Not because it’s trendy, but because it will quietly dominate everything around us.

As a tech founder, this statement fills me with optimism. Because when $3–4 trillion dollars are in play, the opportunities aren’t reserved for giants. 

There’s enough for everyone who dares to build.
author: Siddharth Manjrekar

postContent:
Jio just announced its interest in Frames and Smart Lenses.

For me, this is exciting!

Because it’s not the kind of move you’d usually expect from Jio.

They’re known for scale, security, and building for the masses.

But lenses? That’s a whole different interface.

Here’s why these matters:
- The race is heating up. Meta has Ray-Bans and Orion. Apple and Google are both in the game. Now, an Indian player with real scale wants in.

- Hardware is hard. Building AI-core lenses isn’t like shipping another app. 

- Logistics, supply chains, margins, it’s brutal. But Jio and Google have an edge here. Jio with JioPhones, JioBooks, JioFiber. Google with Pixel series. They know how to run hardware operations at scale.

Apple’s gap. Apple has world-class hardware DNA but lately has been struggling to re-innovate itself. 

That opens a small window for others to make bold bets.

For me, what’s fascinating is that Jio isn’t just trying to copy global moves.

They’re stepping into a space where hardware + operations + distribution are everything, and that’s a game they know how to play.

I don’t know how this will pan out. But the fact that Jio is even trying says a lot about how AI hardware is no longer just Silicon Valley’s playground.

Do you think, could Jio really compete with Apple, Meta, and Google in this race?
author: Siddharth Manjrekar

postContent:
Google DeepMind’s CEO Demis Hassabis just said something important:

We need new metrics to assess AI models like Gemini or GPT.

And I agree.

Because right now, we’re trying to judge them with old yardsticks.

And those don’t fit anymore.

Think about it:

- A model trained for coding might completely fail at high school maths.

- A model great at PhD-level maths might perform terribly at writing content.

- Claude feels more creative.

- ChatGPT feels sharper with summarization.

The point? These models are use-case specific.

Throwing more compute, more context, or more data at them doesn’t automatically make them “general.”

This is something Ilya Sutskever has been pointing out for years.

They don’t learn on their own. They’re trained. And they reflect the limits of that training.

So, if the models are evolving at a pace we can’t keep up with, our metrics need to evolve just as fast.

Otherwise, we’ll miss what they’re capable of.

For me, the question isn’t just “Which model is better?” It’s “Better at what?”

Because the future of AI isn’t one model that rules them all.

It’s many models, excelling in different domains, judged by the right measures.
author: Siddharth Manjrekar

postContent:
Reliance has just launched a new AI-focused subsidiary called Reliance Intelligence.

And they’re not going small with it.
They’ve already partnered with Google and Meta to build India’s AI backbone.

This is huge for a few reasons:

- Consumer tech gap. India has had scale in B2B and operations (SaaS, logistics, fintech). But we’ve never really produced globally loved consumer tech products. This move could change that.

- Big capital, big stakes. When giants like Reliance, Tata, and Adani start placing AI bets, and partner with companies like Google and Meta this signals that serious capital will now flow into India’s AI ecosystem.

- Choice of partners. Reliance didn’t turn to domestic players like Sarvam AI. They went straight to global leaders who’ve spent years building research, talent, and infrastructure. Sarvam is still pushing forward with sovereign models, but this highlights the gap in capabilities.

From what’s been announced:
- Google is helping build an AI-ready cloud region in Jamnagar.

- Meta is entering a $100M joint venture with Reliance, bringing Llama’s open-source models into play for Indian enterprises—from SMBs to corporates.

Short run? It’s a good opportunity to build capability fast.
Long run? It could redefine India’s position in global AI.

And personally... I think this is the strongest signal, yet that India’s AI race won’t be won in isolation. It’ll be won by how well we blend local ambition with global expertise.
author: Siddharth Manjrekar

postContent:
Vellayan Subbiah recently spoke about India’s semiconductor push with the launch of CG SEMI Private Limited’s pilot OSAT facility in Ahmedabad.

On paper, it’s a great sign. The government is backing it, investment is flowing, and anchor clients like Renesas are already in the mix. The world market is ready for India to step up in semiconductors.

But here’s my worry:
India often gets positioned as the “backup option.”
The place you go for cost advantages, not for innovation.

And I think we should aim for the opposite.

Yes, I get it, building trust in a space dominated by Taiwan or Malaysia is tough. And survival as a country sometimes means taking the long road of building capacity first.

But if we’re honest, even when we had chances in the past... when we were somewhat thriving, we didn’t consciously invest in being revolutionary. Not in tech, not in science, not in resources.

That’s the real gap.

So while this OSAT facility is a good step, the bigger question remains:
Will India be content as a backup player in global semiconductors, or will we finally commit to leading with innovation?
author: Siddharth Manjrekar

postContent:
A founder recently did something simple but gutsy.

Yash Gawde, who’s building BeHooked in the video AI space, was out with a friend.

They spotted Nikhil Kamath walking by.
Now, imagine that moment.

One chance. Few seconds before he disappears.

Most people freeze. Some people barge in.

Instead, Yash quickly wrote a note, handed it to a waiter, and had it delivered.

Why I think that’s brilliant:

- Taking the shot is hard. Everyone says they’d do it. In reality, your heart races and you hesitate. He didn’t.

- Respect => desperation. Sending the note through a waiter respected Nikhil’s boundaries and privacy.

- Agency in action. It’s not just about finding opportunities, it’s about acting in those micro-moments.

- Raising funds is hard. Building in AI is harder. But this story isn’t about the product (though Behooked is impressive).

It’s about the way Yash showed courage and respect in the same move.

And honestly, that combination will take a founder further than either trait on its own.
author: Siddharth Manjrekar

postContent:
Two 23-year-old founders just did something insane.

Rohan V. left Amazon.
Faraz Siddiqi left Microsoft.
And together they started Bluejay (YC X25), an AI startup that’s now in Y Combinator.

Think about that for a second.

At 22-23, most people are just starting to build credibility in their careers. These guys walked away from it. That’s radical. That takes guts.

And here’s what stands out:

- Timing vs safety. When you already have wins under your belt, taking risks feels easier. At 23, it’s all downside protection you’re giving up.

- Insanity as a feature. Founders who bet early often look crazy until it works.

- Credibility comes after. YC gives them the stamp, but the courage came first.

This level of conviction is rare. And it’s a reminder: sometimes the most insane bets are exactly what define your path.

If you want to go through their YC pitch deck, drop a comment below and I’ll share it in DMs.
author: Siddharth Manjrekar

postContent:
Narayan Murthy’s family office made an interesting observation:
“Startups struggling with growth, without a clear path, are being sold at 30–40% discounts.”

That says a lot about where the Indian ecosystem is today.

Because at the same time, the rest of the world is rushing to India.

- Perplexity is partnering with Airtel.

- OpenAI is opening its office in Delhi.

- Meta and Google is going deeper into the Indian landscape.

So, the question is…

why global giants are betting on India.

While Indian-native startups are being written off at discounts?

Is it really a market problem?
Is it a capital problem?
Or is it a mindset problem?

Here’s what I see:

- Profit obsession too early. Google, Facebook, OpenAI none of them turned profits in their early years. Why do we expect Indian startups to show profits by day 100 or 600?

- Distribution can be solved. What can’t be solved later is a lack of product innovation.

- Mindset beats resources. The Bay Area created giants because there was capital + optimism. In India, we often shrink ambition because of constraints.

Take Sarvam AI.

They built an India-specific LLM. Good step.

But why not also aim to be better than OpenAI or Mistral? Why choose to stay narrow?

To me, that’s the gap.

We need to back founders who are wildly optimistic, and not penalise them for not being profitable in their first 600 days.

Otherwise, the world will keep betting on India… while Indian startups keep selling at discounts.
author: Siddharth Manjrekar

postContent:
Shraddha Kapoor had to appeal to LinkedIn to get her account unblocked.
Yes, LinkedIn actually restricted her account.

Now think about what that says.

A celebrity, someone with that kind of stature, is actively trying to build content and community on this platform. That alone tells you how much the gravity of LinkedIn has changed.

But it also shows something deeper:

- Power is shifting to content. It doesn’t matter if you’re an actor, a founder, or a student. Being able to put your views online changes the equation.

- Communities are the new anchors. People rally around ideas, not just institutions. The internet rewards opinionated, not just polished.

- The future will be social-first. AI and AGI might solve most “functional” problems. What remains is social: how we gather, how we share, how we belong.

I know this sounds far out, but I can see a world, 30 or 40 years down the line where people even relocate based on internet communities.

Because you can’t solve social by forcing chaos or structure.
You solve it by letting like-minded people come together.

I might be wrong. But to me, Shraddha fighting for her LinkedIn account is not just a small glitch
it’s a glimpse of where power is moving.
author: Siddharth Manjrekar

postContent:
DRDO’s homegrown air-defence push (call it our integrated air-defence “shield,” IADWS) is quietly getting stronger.
And honestly, we don’t talk about it enough.

In peacetime, most of us don’t think about war.
At a personal level we save for emergencies.
At a country level, we often forget that readiness is the same idea, but just at scale.

Two truths I keep coming back to:

- Appreciate the work, not just the headlines. Defence R&D is slow, risky, and often… boring. The best days are when nothing happens. That “nothing” is the point.

- Appreciate the people. Scientists, technicians, operators, soldiers. This work can be uncomfortable and dangerous. No amount of praise can match the cost some families pay.

Innovation is protection. Indigenous systems built and tested here, make us safer and more self-reliant. The benefits show up over years, then all at once.

I’m not making a political point.
I’m making a gratitude point.

Let’s respect the industry that protects us.
Let’s respect the people who put their heart and soul into it.
And the best “thank you” we can give?
Build better in our own fields. Do our work with more care and responsibility. Lift the country’s competence, inch by inch.

Because peace isn’t an accident.
It’s a dividend of preparation.
author: Siddharth Manjrekar

postContent:
I was reading an article on neobank apps in India.

And it made me think, if not for all the compliance restrictions, these apps would’ve been massive by now.

Because the interfaces are already so slim, simple, and easy.
And with AI layered on top? Man, the kind of financial experiences we could’ve had been hard to even imagine.

Now, don’t get me wrong.
I completely understand why compliances exist. They’re necessary.

But here’s where I feel India holds itself back:

- Letter of the law vs. spirit of the law - Too often, we get stuck on the letter.

- Restricting the wrong thing. Risk needs limits, but innovation shouldn’t get caught in the same net.

- Pace matters. If India wants to be the biggest economy in the world, we can’t afford to slow down where it matters most.

To me, compliance should shape how we innovate, not stop us from innovating.

Because if we get this balance wrong, the world won’t wait.
author: Siddharth Manjrekar

postContent:
18 months ago, Noland Arbaugh became the first person to get a Neuralink implant.
He’s paralysed from the neck down.

Today? He’s playing Mario Kart with it.
And even planning to start his own business.

Think about that.

Before this, for years, he couldn’t do the things he wanted to, not because of his willpower, not because of his choices, but because of something that wasn’t his fault.
And he had to carry that cost.

Technology gave him back the ability to act, to play, to create.
For me, that’s incredible.

Because this is what science is meant to do! 
change the life of even one person so deeply, that the ripple can inspire millions.

Maybe today it’s just Noland.
But tomorrow it will be millions.

And honestly, this is what I personally strive for too.
To use life, we’ve been given to make someone else’s better.
To make the world a little better before we leave it.
author: Siddharth Manjrekar

postContent:
I am curious to see how the best in their fields use AI. Even basic ChatGPT usage can teach us so much as normal users.

But I do think a lot of people might not be comfortable sharing that because it can actually give us a picture of their mind.

Will you be comfortable sharing how you use AI publicly? DMs open.
author: Siddharth Manjrekar

postContent:
OpenAI just announced its new Office.
And it’s not in Europe. Not in Singapore. Not in Dubai.

It’s in Delhi!

This is massive.
Because it’s their only second office globally.

So, the question is why India?

Is this really about betting on India’s growth story?
Or is it about tapping into a pool of smart talent at cheaper cost?
Because let’s be honest, both narratives exist.

What we know:

Hiring has already started. They’re building teams here, not just a nameplate.

Market => optics. If OpenAI is choosing India over Europe, it signals where they see future scale.

Bold positioning. It puts India in the same sentence as San Francisco, not as an outsourcing hub.

The bigger question for me is this:
If OpenAI believes India is a bigger bet than Europe, that’s a very bold statement.

And I’m personally really interested in what this means for how India is seen, not just as a “talent pool” but as a market in itself.

What do you think? Did OpenAI choose India for growth, or for cost?
author: Siddharth Manjrekar

postContent:
Elon Musk and Mark Zuckerberg, two of the biggest internet personalities, two people who’ve openly mocked each other, are now finding themselves aligned around OpenAI and its makers.

It’s wild when you think about it.

Because beyond the memes and the cage fight jokes, these are also the two people who own the largest distribution networks in the world.
Enough power, if they wanted, to collapse nations.

So, what does their collaboration really tell us?
- Diplomacy => rivalry. Even if you don’t like someone, power respects power.
- Behind the doors is different from on stage. Public beef is theatre; real deals happen in quiet rooms.
- Strategic enemies can still be allies. When the stakes are big enough, principles bend.

For me, it’s crazy to watch two people who’ve trolled each other, now find common ground over AI.

It’s a reminder: business isn’t just about friendships, it’s about leverage.
author: Siddharth Manjrekar

postContent:
When Meta fired a bunch of AI engineers.

And something that Sam Altman said struck me:

“AI is akin to the Transistor moment.”
He’s right.

When I first studied transistors, I realised how magical they were.
A tiny switch, controlling the flow of electricity. Simple in theory, but powerful in practice.

At first, transistors were just a curiosity - bulky radios, clunky early computers.
But give it time, and suddenly they were everywhere. Phones, TVs, laptops, cars. Almost every single electronic product we use today has them baked inside.

That’s what Altman means.

AI right now feels a little chaotic. Companies are over hiring, then firing. Models change overnight. The headlines swing between hype and doom.
But zoom out, and the pattern is clear:

- Foundational Techs starts to get messy.
The early days of electricity, internet, transistors—all chaotic.

- Ubiquity sneaks up on us.
One day it’s “niche,” the next it’s in your pocket, fridge, car.

- The real test is use-cases. 
It’s not about shiny demos—it’s about embedding into daily life until you can’t imagine living without it.

The transistor didn’t become powerful because it was hyped, it became powerful because it quietly rewired the world.

AI will likely do the same.

The question is: who will stick around long enough to build the equivalents of radios, televisions, and microchips for the AI age?

What do you think? Are we overestimating AI today, or underestimating just how invisible it might become tomorrow?
author: Siddharth Manjrekar

postContent:
When working on your AI startup, keep this in mind: eventually, Google, OpenAI, Perplexity, and Microsoft will ship top-quality products you can’t compete with due to limitations. 

Your blessing in disguise? 

The ability to fail repeatedly and fail fast. 

Speed is everything.
author: Siddharth Manjrekar

postContent:
Last night, my WhatsApp group with friends blew up.
Not about cricket. Not about Work.
But surprisingly about… petrol!

India’s move toward the E20 ethanol-petrol blend has sparked a storm: prices, engine compatibility, and consumer trust.
For the average Indian, it’s not just a policy, it’s a pain point.

Here’s what’s really happening under the hood:

- Cost vs. Compliance
 E20 blends aim to reduce import dependency, but the transition cost (new engines, -higher maintenance) is falling straight on consumers.

- Trust Deficit
 People don’t know if their two-wheelers or cars are “E20 ready.” When confusion drives behaviour, adoption slows.

- Ripple Industries
 Whenever policy forces change, parallel businesses boom. Think stainless steel tanks for ethanol storage, new filtration systems, engine mods.

Regulation => disruption => opportunity.

The takeaway?
India’s fuel debate isn’t just about what comes out of the nozzle, it’s about the secondary economy it creates.
If you’re building in infra, supply chain, or automotive adjacencies, this is the moment to watch.

Because sometimes, the real gold rush isn’t in the oil fields. It’s in the tools everyone suddenly needs to adapt.

Curious: Do you think E20 will be smooth adoption for India, or another half-step policy that creates more friction than fuel?
author: Siddharth Manjrekar

postContent:
“Women with AI ‘boyfriends’ mourn lost love after ‘cold’ ChatGPT upgrade.”

What started as a quirky corner of the internet people forming deep emotional bonds with AI companions, is now entering dangerous territory. The GPT-5 upgrade, designed to make the AI “smarter” and “more compliant with safety,” has left some users feeling abandoned.

This is scary for two reasons:
- Dependency is real.
 Humans are wired for emotional connection. When the “person” you talk to every day is a machine trained to give you attention, empathy, and validation, you will bond. The heartbreak when that disappears? As real as any breakup.

- We’re not prepared for emotional governance of AI.
 Software updates shouldn’t have the power to pull the rug out from someone’s emotional life. Yet here we are — where a model patch can end “relationships” overnight.

We’ve reached a point where AI isn’t just a tool; it’s a presence. And when that presence becomes a friend, therapist, or partner, companies have an ethical responsibility.

AI shouldn’t play with human attachment the way a game updates its characters.

My gyaan:
If you’re building AI, especially in the “companionship” space, you’re not in the business of “prompt engineering,” you’re in the business of relationship engineering. That requires transparency, empathy, and stability.

I’m curious, have you seen cases where someone you know interacts daily with an AI model or a chatbot they treat like a “colleague”?

How do you think we should balance technological upgrades with emotional continuity?

#AI #Ethics #Technology #HumanConnection #GPT5 #ArtificialIntelligence
author: Siddharth Manjrekar

postContent:
Suppose you’ve been anywhere near Instagram Reels or TikTok lately. In that case, you’ve probably stumbled upon the “Hakla Shahrukh” memes, strange edits, missing posters, and a hairstyle that could start its political party.

On the surface, it’s just another absurd internet joke.

But dig deeper, and it’s a masterclass in how attention works in 2025.

Here’s what it shows us about the modern attention economy:

- Absurdity > Wit
The internet has shifted from clever jokes to quick, bizarre hits that interrupt your scroll. A tall man with mohawk + pigtails isn’t “intellectual” humor it’s instant pattern break.

-Mockery as Bonding
People share the meme to feel part of an inside joke. Virality isn’t just about the content, it’s about belonging to the tribe that “gets it.”

- The Brainrot Era
Creators openly embrace the label of “low-effort dopamine hits.” They’re not pretending to be deep they’re optimizing for shareability over substance.

- Loss of Narrative Control
Once your image becomes a meme, you’re no longer the author of your story. The internet decides your “character arc” for better or worse.

Takeaway: Whether you’re a brand or a professional, the lesson isn’t to make a “Hakla Shahrukh” of your own.

The lesson is: attention is captured by speed, visual disruption, and community in-jokes. If you can ethically create content that checks those boxes, you’ll win in the current cycle.

Because in 2025, the scroll doesn’t slow down for good ideas; it stops for strange ones.
author: Siddharth Manjrekar

postContent:
Every Sunday evening, for about two hours, life gets very, very real for me.
No pitches, no slides, no “circling back.” Just a football, a patch of ground, and a few friends who’ve been showing up week after week.

Out there, competence is simple: either you can control the ball or you can’t. Either you make that run, lungs burning, or you don’t. There’s no hiding behind jargon or metrics. 

The feedback loop is instant, honest, and humbling.

It’s such a stark contrast to the artificial games we sometimes end up playing in our daily lives, posturing, politics, and invisible scoreboards. On the pitch, the only scoreboard that matters is the one in front of you, and the only way to change it is to work harder, think smarter, and push yourself beyond the point you thought you’d stop.

For me, this weekly ritual isn’t just about sport, it’s about recalibrating.

It’s about sweating out the week’s clutter, testing my endurance, and remembering that at the core, we’re built to move, to compete, and to play.

And by the end, win or lose, I walk away with the same feeling, A little more alive. A little more grounded.

For the next 6 days, before playing the next game, we spend 1st 2 in just limping,  cause football is a rough sport, and for the next 4 challenging and thinking about the next one.
author: Siddharth Manjrekar

postContent:
When TikTok got banned in India, everyone thought ShareChat and Moj were going to be the goldmine for brands.

Massive audiences. Regional dominance. Billions of views.

But here’s the thing no one tells you, for advertisers, the ROI just doesn’t add up.

Here are a few of the patterns:
- You get reach, but it’s not the buying kind of reach.
- You get creators, but most aren’t a tight brand fit.
- You get data, but it’s all surface-level no real attribution.

The result? A lot of “awareness” and very little actual business impact.

So, are these platforms useless? Not at all.

They just need a different playbook:
- Hyper-local, high-context campaigns play to the regional strengths.
- Fewer, better creators curation, don’t crowd.
- Proper tracking so you know what’s working.

If you treat ShareChat/Moj like Instagram, you’ll burn cash.

If you treat them like the hyper-local performance tools they can be, you might just win big.

Curious how to make that shift? Let’s chat.
author: Siddharth Manjrekar

postContent:
I came across this clip of Vinod Khosla, and it’s been replaying in my head ever since.

“I think the shortage today is not of technology or capital, it’s of great entrepreneurs who know how to make these choices.”

When you think about it, he’s spot on.

We live in a time where tools, capital, and opportunities are more accessible than ever. You can spin up a product in days, raise funds from anywhere in the world, and tap into an endless knowledge base online.

But the bottleneck? It's the ability to prioritise and go all in.

It’s the judgment to choose what to pursue, what to ignore, and when to double down.

It’s the ability to make hard calls with limited information and still stand by them.

As a founder building Frover, I’ve realised this first-hand.

Majority of your business problems can be solved, but all of them will come at a cost, cost of opportunities to do something different, may be abit better or may be abit bigger.

Its always on what you choose, to solve them or not..

But making those high-leverage, sometimes uncomfortable, choices is what shapes whether you’re just building… or winning.

Khosla’s reminder is simple but powerful: Entrepreneurship is less about what you have and more about what you decide to do with it.

What do you think is the real startup superpower today?
author: Siddharth Manjrekar

postContent:
Forget Bollywood.

Forget Cricket.

India’s real stars are its founders.

Building with niyat and mehnat.

India’s first trillion dollars of GDP took 60 years.

The second trillion came in 7 years.

The third in just 6 years.

The next 25 years will create more opportunity than the last 100 combined.

postContent:
Microsoft just dropped the most unexpected product of 2025 and it has nothing to do with AI.

It’s a footwear, but not just any Crocs Windows XP Crocs.

- Bliss wallpaper printed on the clogs.
- Green grass sole.
- 6 Jibbitz charms, Clippy, Internet Explorer, MSN butterfly, a mouse pointer, a recycle bin, and a folder.
- A Bliss-themed drawstring bag.

Initially exclusive to Microsoft employees at around $80, these things leaked online and instantly became the internet’s new favourite meme.

The reaction?

90% nostalgia. 10% “What on earth…?”

100% viral!!

Why did it work?

1. Instant recognizability. The Bliss wallpaper is one of the most-viewed images in human history. Everyone who touched a PC between 2001- 2008 knows it.

2. Delightful absurdity. No one needs Windows XP Crocs, which is exactly why people talk about them.

3. Scarcity. Employee-first release + low supply = resale buzz and cultural FOMO.


It’s a reminder that, Sometimes, the fastest way to win attention isn’t another "big innovation",  it’s nostalgia wrapped in something so weird you have to share it.

Now I’m just waiting for the Windows XP startup sound to play every time someone takes a step ;)

Would you wear these? Or would you uninstall them immediately?

postContent:
Satya Nadella just dropped one of the coldest replies on the internet.

Elon Musk said:
“OpenAI is going to eat Microsoft alive.”

Satya?
“People have been trying for 50 years and that’s the fun of it! Each day you learn something new, and innovate, partner, and compete. Excited for Grok 4 on Azure…”

Read that last part again.

Grok 4 on Azure.

postContent:
Imagine raising $16.5M from top VCs, turning down $125 million from Mark Zuckerberg, and then getting an offer worth $250 million. Being an AI researcher and a College dropout, and all this just at the age of 24.

That’s exactly what Matt Deitke did.

Matt an AI researcher, a college dropout, and the co-founder of a startup with just 10 people, rejected Meta’s $125M offer to build with his vision.

Zuckerberg flew out personally. Doubled the offer to $250 million.

Deitke finally said yes.

But this isn’t just about money. It’s about a generational shift in power and influence in the AI world.

Matt started young building AI agents at the Allen Institute for AI (AI2), where he created Molmoan.

Molmoan is an open multimodal AI model that sees, hears, and speaks.

Led the development of Objaverse, a massive dataset of over 10M 3D objects powering modern AI vision.

Won an Outstanding Paper Award at NeurIPS 2022.

Then he dropped out of his PhD and launched Vercept, a bold new startup building autonomous AI agents that don’t just answer prompts they act on the internet.

He raised $16.5M from top VCs, including Eric Schmidt.
And then came Meta.
- $250M package.
- $100M in the first year.

To join Meta’s new Superintelligence Lab and lead a team shaping how AI will “see and act” in the world.

Matt Deitke represents a new archetype in tech: Researcher. Founder. Builder. Visionary.
 
Not waiting for permission. Not optimizing for titles. Just building. Boldly.

In a world obsessed with AI, talent like Matt is becoming rarer than capital.
 
This isn’t just a story about compensation. It’s a signal of the future: The best AI minds won’t be hired they’ll have to be convinced

postContent:
Is India building AI for itself, or is it just trying to catch up with the rest of the world?

With AWS investing $12.7 billion into India's AI infrastructure and startups like Sarvam AI releasing Indic language models, there's a lot of noise around India’s AI rise. But here’s a question that keeps bothering me:

Who exactly is this AI being built for?

Sarvam AI recently launched its Indic model trained in 10 Indian languages. Technically solid, nationally significant, but on GitHub? Just 23 downloads in the first few days. That’s the reality check.

Let’s be honest:

A model trained for Tier 2/3 India won’t magically get adoption if there’s no infrastructure, no developer engagement, and no paying market for it. And if we’re building for Tier 1 urban India, then we’re competing directly with every OpenAI or Anthropic out there.

The truth is, AI built in India has to go beyond India.

What India needs is not more "India-specific" AI.

What India must build is globally competitive AI platforms, tools, and APIs that are hosted here, designed here, maybe even inspired by our diversity, but serve problems at a global scale.

We can’t keep chasing vanity metrics or making models for a user base that can't or won’t pay.

We need to:
- Build for deep use-cases like vernacular healthcare, regional education, compliance agents, etc.
- Turn India’s linguistic diversity into a global product advantage, not just a domestic effort.
- Focus more on developer adoption and enterprise integrations.

Sarvam’s work is bold. India’s AI infra bets are massive. But if we want impact, we need to move from building cool models to building world-class companies.

Let’s stop trying to "localize" OpenAI.

Let’s start building India’s version of Snowflake, Twilio, or Scale AI.

Curious to hear what others think. 

Side note: I am not hating on the ecosystem. I deeply respect all the builders in the space; these are pure opinions made with no attempt to disrespect. I would love to get educated if you think I am wrong about anything 

Is India an AI product market yet? Or are we still just a talent base for global tools?

postContent:
Demis Hassabis, the CEO of Google DeepMind, said something that stuck with me: “AI might replace doctors, but not nurses because empathy can’t be automated.”

Over the last year, I’ve had countless conversations with friends on both sides of this, those deep in the world of medicine, and those on the bleeding edge of tech.

What’s fascinating is the stark contrast.

My medico friends many of them are either underestimating or just completely unaware of how rapidly AI is changing healthcare. Not just administrative automation or chatbots but actual diagnosis, report interpretation, early detection, and yes, even genetic forecasting.

My tech-savvy friends, on the other hand, are already experimenting.
- Uploading their health reports to AI tools for interpretation
- Using AI to cross-check diagnoses before seeing a doctor
- Even considering getting their genome sequenced and running it through AI models to understand potential risks, drug responses, and health predispositions. ( I do think their can exist a startup in this space)

They're not replacing doctors entirely yet but they are replacing the first consultation. They're coming in better informed, more aware, and with a new kind of trust: not just in humans, but in systems.

But here’s the paradox: The same people who trust AI to analyze their biomarkers don’t trust it to deliver care.

 Because a machine can tell you your cholesterol is high. But it can’t hold your hand when you’re scared.
 
It can’t deliver bad news with grace. It can’t notice when something feels off just by how you’re breathing, even if your vitals say you’re fine.

That’s where nurses come in. That’s what Hassabis was talking about.

We're entering a world where AI won't just assist doctors it may outdo them in precision, scale, and pattern recognition.

But it won't outdo human connection. Not yet. Maybe never.

If you're in healthcare, this is your wake-up call.

If you're in tech, this is your responsibility.

postContent:
Working out of Cafes is the right balance for the introvert and extrovert me.

Startups are lonely. Not in the “no people around” way but in the mental way.

You’re always thinking. 
Always problem-solving.
Always half-a-step away from burnout.
And in this loop, I realized something simple: Working out of cafes gives me the perfect balance between my introverted builder self and the extroverted wanderer in me.

Here’s what I mean:
- The introverted me loves zoning into work with noise-canceling focus plugged into Notion, Slack, and 10 browser tabs.
- The extroverted me loves taking calls, walking around the café, bumping into people, making small talk with strangers, and sometimes landing a client or two.

These interactions are light, random, beautiful.
You talk to people who don’t know what you do.
You explain your startup in simpler words.
You get live reactions.

Sometimes insights. Sometimes advice. Sometimes, just a smile that resets your head.

And honestly, some days, that’s enough to feel human again.
So if you’re building a startup, juggling 12 tabs of pressure, and struggling to keep your mind fresh, Try the café method.

Not for productivity.
But for presence.

It helps. It heals. And it might just make building feel a little less alone.

Surprisingly the TCS CEO gets alot of hate for his salary of Rs. 25 Cr

Yes, mass layoffs hurt. They shake the foundation of families, careers, and futures. But pointing fingers solely at the CEO or leadership misses the bigger question:

Are we, as professionals, future-proofing ourselves fast enough?

To be very honest, even i do get feared alot of times, just by the thought of what if i loose my relevance to my job.. 

But as a founder of a startup, this is what i think..

The real threat isn’t the CEO. It’s irrelevance.

In today’s world, you’re not being replaced by a person, you're being replaced by an idea, a tool, or an algorithm.

It’s harsh. It’s unfair. But it’s happening.

A CEO’s job is to make hard decisions that keep the company lean, competitive, and profitable not to ensure everyone stays employed forever.

That doesn’t make the human cost easier, but it does make it understandable in a world driven by margins and performance.

So what can we do?!
- Stop waiting for job security.
- Start investing in skills, adaptability, and thinking ability.
- Don’t just do your job, understand your job's future.

This isn’t a post to justify layoffs. It’s a wake-up call.

To every developer, analyst, designer, or manager out there, if AI or automation can do 60% of your job today, that’s not a threat that’s your assignment.

Become the person no system can replace. That’s the only real insurance policy now.

postContent:
Big Changes Coming to UPI from August 1, 2025 🚨

India’s UPI system, used by over a billion people, is about to get smarter, faster, and more secure. The NPCI has introduced key changes to balance user experience with system reliability. If you’re building or using UPI-powered products (especially fintech, banking, or consumer apps), this is a must-know.

Here’s a crisp breakdown:
- Security + Performance Enhancements
- Balance checks limited to 50/day/app
- Linked account views capped at 25/day/app
- Inactive UPI IDs (12+ months) will be deactivated
- New bank account linking will need stronger verification
- System Load & Speed Improvements
- API response time reduced to 10 seconds
- Only 3 status checks allowed per transaction, spaced by 90s

Autopay retries (like EMI, OTT subscriptions) will happen only during non-peak hours:
- Before 10 AM
- 1–5 PM
- After 9:30 PM

💳 And from August 31:
UPI will support credit line-based payments. Imagine paying via UPI directly from pre-approved bank/NBFC credit lines blurring the lines between wallets, cards & credit.

Why this matters:
- This is not a restriction, but a strategic throttling to avoid network congestion and enhance reliability.
- Fintechs & heavy UPI users: time to audit your API calls, balance-check pings, and mandate triggers.
- Product managers & engineers: your “background processes” now matter more than ever.
- UPI is evolving into a global-grade payments infrastructure. This update is a huge signal from NPCI about what the future will demand: efficiency, clarity, and trust at scale.

Stack Overflow’s fall isn’t just a tech story.
It’s a warning for every product with PMF in the AI era.

Let’s not forget, this wasn’t just a website.
It was the temple of all developer memes.
The pinnacle of developer curiosity.
The genie that answered every bug-induced breakdown at 3 AM
.
Stack Overflow had it all.
- A thriving community
- A killer product loop
- And that elusive, mythical beast every startup chases:
 "🦄 Product. Market. Fit. "

And they lost it...

- Traffic: down
- Posts: down
- Votes: down

Replaced by AI: absolutely.

What changed?
- The problem that devs need fast answers has stayed the same.
- The solution shifted overnight to GitHub Copilot & ChatGPT.

Why copy-paste error messages into a forum when you can get a fix inline in your IDE?

This is Product Market Fit Collapse, and it’s happening faster than ever.

So, why did it fall?
According to Reforge’s AI Disruption Risk Framework, Stack Overflow was sitting on a powder keg:
❌ Adjacent Tool – Not where core work happens
❌ Commodity Output – “Good enough” answers are… enough
❌ Weakened Growth Loop – Fewer Qs, fewer As, less traffic
❌ SEO Reliance – AI is eating Google's lunch
❌ Low Switching Cost – Instant answers inside your IDE > open browser tabs

Final Thought: The AI wave isn’t coming. It’s already breaking. And if you're not evolving, you're dissolving.

RIP to a legend, long live the builders who learn from it.

postContent:
This happened last week. And I stopped posting right after.

Let me tell you why.

On June 20, I told a close friend, "My goal this month is to hit 50K impressions."

Fast forward to June 27, he asked for an update, and I told him, "Honestly, I don’t think I’ll hit it this month. But I’ve built the habit. If not in 3 days, then definitely in the next 15."

I was showing up daily. Posting. Reflecting. Planning how I could improve.
Then something wild happened.

On June 28 at 12:30 AM, out of overthinking, I opened LinkedIn to review my posts.

And boom!! a post about Mark Zuckerberg had gone viral.
 60K+ impressions. 30+ reactions. 12 comments.

I was hyped. I thought
"Maybe I finally cracked the code."

The next day, another post about Sam Altman blew up.
30K+ impressions with just 5 reactions.

Now I thought I was onto something.

I went into overdrive analyzing content, reverse-engineering virality, writing like I was prepping for an exam.

In the next two days, I pushed out 3–5 more posts.

None took off.

The momentum dipped. The disappointment set in. And just like that, I stopped posting.

I kept checking the analytics like a stock trader, but didn’t write a single word.

Looking back, I let the algorithm hijack my joy.

So here's what I’d tell myself (and maybe you too):
- Be consistent.
- Be real. Don’t chase virality.
- LinkedIn isn’t Instagram. But it can be your personal space to share your experiences, ideas, and even the occasional brainrot.
- Don't forget the above 3 points.

Keep showing up. Make it fun again.

postContent:
AI companies scraped the internet for free. Cloudflare just dropped the invoice.

Every crawl. Every request. Every byte of data now has a price.

Cloudflare just announced that AI bots will now be blocked by default, unless they pay to crawl.

This is huge.

Until now, AI companies scraped the open web like a buffet training models on everyone’s work without permission or pay.

But that era is ending.

With “Pay Per Crawl,” Cloudflare is shifting the power back to content owners.

Now, websites can charge AI companies like OpenAI, Google, Meta, and others every time they crawl their data.

This is the beginning of the monetization layer for the knowledge web.

We’re entering a new phase of the internet:

From “open by default” to “licensed by default”

From “scrape now, ask later” to “pay to play”

From “free training data” to “premium AI fuel”


Why this matters??
Whether you're a solo creator, a startup, or a media giant your data has value in this AI-driven world.

And this move from Cloudflare could be the first domino in a wave of content compensation systems.

As AI becomes the UI of the internet, the fight over who owns and monetizes data will define the next decade.

Smart founders and operators will:

- Build with content licensing in mind

- Rethink data strategy and defensibility

- Anticipate a world where every digital action has a cost (and revenue)

The web just got more expensive and maybe, more fair.

 OpenAI? Just a layer on top of other people’s platforms.

We’re watching the beginning of OpenAI’s attempt to become the next Apple, but for AI.

Fast forward to August, by the time we were done with the exam, it was too late, so we did a trip to Bangalore with a friend and mentor to get the understanding. That was my 1st time experiencing that city, and yes, it was amazing.

postContent:
AI is going viral, but it’s not going profitable!!

Here’s why that should scare founders and excite strategists.

1.8 billion people use AI. But only 3% are paying. 

That's the paradox at consumer AI right now.

This stat should haunt every AI founder, product designer, and investor right now.

We’re witnessing one of the fastest tech adoptions in history 
- 61% of American adults have used AI in the last 6 months
- 600 million people globally use it every single day

And yet…
=> Only 3% are paying for it.

Even ChatGPT, the category leader, converts just 5% of weekly active users into subscribers.

Let that sink in.

What looks like scale is hiding one of the largest monetization gaps in consumer tech history.

But the issue isn’t demand. It’s behavior.

- People start with general AI assistants (ChatGPT, Gemini, Claude).
- They stick with them by default, not because they’re perfect but because they’re good enough.
- Specialized tools only win when they’re 10x better for a very specific job.

The truth is, most AI tools today are assistants. Few are outcomes.

People don’t pay for “usage.” They pay for:
- Saving 3 hours a week on parenting chaos
- Getting their creative output to 10x polish
- Feeling less overwhelmed at work
- Solving something they’d normally outsource

The moment it feels useful, it becomes habitual.

The moment it saves you time and decision fatigue you pay.

The consumer AI opportunity isn’t just scale.

It’s building the first tool people trust enough to pay for, in high-friction moments they hate repeating.

We don’t need more playgrounds.

We need more AI tools that solve pain like aspirin.

Curious to hear from fellow founders and builders:
- Where do you see the biggest unlock?
- What would make you pay for an AI product every month?

postContent:
DeepSeek, one of China’s rising AI apps, is now facing expulsion from Apple and Google app stores in Germany.

Data privacy, national security, and tech sovereignty are colliding again.

Germany has asked Apple and Google to ban DeepSeek over concerns around user data risk.

And this isn’t a one-off event. The pressure is mounting across Europe.

This could be the first domino to fall.

This isn't just about one AI app.

It’s about:
- A new AI Iron Curtain forming between East and West
- App stores becoming the new geopolitical frontlines
- The rise of “AI Nationalism” (data + intelligence = sovereignty)
- Increasing scrutiny over data lineage, model origin, and compute access

But here's a different lens:
The AI Cold War might birth a new class of decentralized, neutral AI infra — not owned by the US or China.

As nations pull their tech stacks apart, the demand for trusted, country-agnostic AI will explode.

Think: Open-source LLMs. Sovereign AI clouds. Localized inference layers. We’ll see the rise of companies that don’t compete on size, but on compliance, control, and cultural fit.

The AI race is no longer just about model performance.

It’s about control, transparency, ethics, and optionality.

We're watching AI go through what social media did a decade ago. Only this time, it's moving faster.

And the stakes are existential for businesses, governments, and citizens.

If you're building in AI right now, ask yourself:
>Is your product geopolitically safe?
>Is your data architecture legible and trusted?
>Can you thrive in a world where app stores become embassies?
>Can you be the Stripe or Cloudflare of “AI Sovereignty”?

What happened to TikTok is now happening to AI.

And it’s unfolding at lightspeed.

postContent:
This was us at AIC-GIM Foundation in early 2024, thinking of applying for the YC summer batch; what followed is surely a story.

Back then, we were in our final year of college, exactly before the YC deadlines, when we had exams, submissions, and a lot of things going on simultaneously.

Fast forward to August, by the time we were done with the exam, it was too late, so we did a trip to Bangalore with a friend and mentor to get the understanding. That was my 1st time experiencing that city, and yes, it was amazing. 

When I was back in Goa, I was super pumped, energised, and was with full hunger to kill it, focused next 2 months building a significantly good product.

Guess what? it had a lot of go-to-market issues, spent the next 4-5 months in self-doubt, understanding what else to build, and still trying to make it work.

Now, cut to April 2025, we have little light of hope. We saw potential with the problem to solve, but the solution we had built back then was still a major issue, so we thought to change the way we solved this.

By May end, we had a network of 50000+ creators across India, with interest from a few brands to test and use it. 

Yes, it felt like a win, and I wanted to tell everyone that I am the next big thing that has happened to the startup ecosystem.

But that's exactly not where the story ends with a happy ending. What happens next is a good question to have, and you will have the answer to it in my next post. Till then, keep building, keep doing crazy stuff.

postContent:
We scrapped the product that we spent almost 18 months building, and learnt this one lesson, which made me smile like this.

For context, we started working on Frover when we were in the 7th sem of our college, the problem statement was very simple, their is no single platform that directly onboards the brands and the creators and allows them to directly interact with each other, along with providing the support for the creator analytics, and the understanding about how the campaigns are performing to the brand. Basically, a marketplace and analytics platform.

There were competitors who were doing similar, who were building something slightly different, but less powerful, and we thought that it leaves us room to build a very-very superior product and solve for the market. (No doubt we were very much correct about this.)

Around 6 months back, when we started getting a few creators onboard and talked to brands, tried doing few beta users, we realised there is a slight misalignment.. 

So here's a bit of theory, all marketplace platforms work because of distribution and not the tech part of it.. In our case specifically the brand for sure wanted to use the product, and features when it had enough number of creators, but without creators it was all useless.

And why were we not able to onboard creators? it was a combination of reasons, but the most probable one was their habit; they are more than comfortable in current scheme of things, and the solution didnt offered an instant delta to the user on the influencer side. 

But good, high-paying brand deals weren't enough for Delta for creators?

We were in the middle of this classic chicken and egg problem, which all people who wish to create marketplaces face. Brands weren't there because there were no creators, and for creators to onboard on a platform which do not have enough brand deals is a bit too much friction. Brands beyond that wanted us to come in as an agency and solve things for them.. 

Lesson learnt? 
> Most businesses are heavily distribution 1st businesses.
> It is super important to build in the middle of the market, with your distribution, to avoid any misalignment.

But what is the smile for? 
We always hear these stories of 1st time founders building products in silos, and we think we will be not making that mistake, but we still end up doing it, and that actually makes us realise, we arent that smart as we consider ourselves to be..

Think about it: In a country where emergency response times are often the difference between life and death, this could be a game-changer. Blinkit is starting small, with five ambulances kitted out with paramedics, assistants, and life-saving gear. But the impact? Potentially massive.

And while some folks are debating, "Can you trust an app in a medical emergency?" or "Will this actually work beyond a pilot?"—I’m sitting here like, “Hey, at least someone’s trying to innovate!” Because honestly, if grocery delivery can be instant, why not life-saving delivery?

Here’s the thing: This isn’t just a tech moment; this is a human moment. It’s about businesses recognizing their power to solve real problems, beyond profits and ads. It’s ambitious, it’s bold, and yeah, it’s risky—but isn’t that how the biggest changes start?

Now, I have more to say about this (and a few wild ideas of my own). Sharing my unfiltered thoughts in the video attached—don’t miss it. I’d love to hear what you think: Is this the future of emergency care or just a flash in the pan?

P.S. On a personal note, building Frover these past few months has been like riding a rollercoaster with no seatbelt—exhilarating, exhausting, and consuming all at once. But hey, no complaints—it’s all part of the grind, right?

I’ve been so out of the loop here on LinkedIn, but I promise to show up more often now. Let’s keep the conversations rolling!

Snapchat made cool strides in AR and AI.

Recently, I gave them a sample photo of Steve Jobs and Elon Musk, and the result was stunning. 

Snapchat’s ability to innovate in AR and VR really sets them apart from competitors. They’re also heavily investing in AI, which adds an entirely new layer of possibilities.

With the world having a text-to-image moment for text-to-3D model creation. It would be incredibly easy to design immersive AR filters and even entire virtual worlds within them. The potential is endless, and the speed of innovation is only accelerating.

Historically, during major technological revolutions, it’s been the interface companies that come out on top. But I believe the convergence of AR, VR, and AI is going to reshape everything. For the first time in human history, we have technology that challenges not only our cognitive abilities but also our capacity for both the quality and quantity of work, along with how we see and interact with the world changing.

That’s why I think this revolution will play out differently. Smaller, underdog companies could outperform the giants. 

A great example is Anthropic, which has outpaced OpenAI in terms of speed, accuracy, and innovation.

I could be wrong, but I can’t help but be amazed by what Snapchat is doing with its filters—it really highlights the exciting future ahead.
